p.span: EMBEDDING TANGLES IN LINKS
DANIEL RUBERMAN
Department of Mathematics
MS 050
Brandeis University
Waltham, MA 02254
ABSTRACT
Extending and reproving a recent result of D. Krebes, we give obstructions to the embedding of a tangle in a link.
Keywords: Tangle, link, determinant, branched covering

div.p: A recent paper [2] of David Krebes poses the following interesting question: given a tangle 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T}, and a link ℒℒcaligraphic-L{\cal L}, when can 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T} sit inside ℒℒcaligraphic-L{\cal L}? A tangle is a 11NUMBER:11-manifold with 4 boundary components, properly embedded in a 3-ball; this is somewhat more general than the usual definition. An embedding of 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T} in ℒℒcaligraphic-L{\cal L} is determined by a ball in S3superscript𝑆3italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{3}, whose intersection with ℒℒcaligraphic-L{\cal L} is the given tangle; we will indicate an embedding by 𝒯↪ℒ↪𝒯ℒcaligraphic-T ARROW:hookrightarrow caligraphic-L{{\cal T}}\hookrightarrow{{\cal L}}. Krebes gives the following simple criterion for when 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{{\cal T}} embeds in ℒℒcaligraphic-L{\cal L}. Complete the tangle to a link in either of the two obvious ways, giving rise to the numerator n⁢(𝒯)𝑛𝒯italic-n OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:)n({{\cal T}}) and denominator d⁢(𝒯)𝑑𝒯italic-d OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:)d({{\cal T}}). For any oriented link ℒℒcaligraphic-L{{\cal L}}, its determinant det⁡(ℒ)ℒLIMITOP:determinant OPEN:( caligraphic-L CLOSE:)\det({{\cal L}}) is defined to be det⁡(V+V′)𝑉superscript𝑉′LIMITOP:determinant OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:plus italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\det(V+V^{\prime}), where V𝑉italic-VV is a Seifert matrix for ℒℒcaligraphic-L{{\cal L}}. Krebes shows

math.alttext: \gcd(\det(n({{\cal T}})),\det(d({{\cal T}})))\ \vrule height 12.0pt depth 6.0% pt width 1px\ \det({{\cal L}})

semantics.annotation: OPFUNCTION:gcd OPEN:( LIMITOP:determinant OPEN:( italic-n OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:) CLOSE:) PUNCT:, LIMITOP:determinant OPEN:( italic-d OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:) CLOSE:) CLOSE:) LIMITOP:determinant OPEN:( caligraphic-L CLOSE:)
\gcd(\det(n({{\cal T}})),\det(d({{\cal T}})))\ \vrule height 12.0pt depth 6.0% pt width 1px\ \det({{\cal L}})

div.p: The proof of Theorem 1 given in [2] is essentially combinatorial, and uses an interpretation of the determinant in terms of link diagrams and the Kauffman bracket. On the other hand, the determinant has a homological interpretation; it is essentially the order of the homology of the 22NUMBER:22-fold branched cover S3superscript𝑆3italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{3}, branched along the link. In this paper, we will prove a simple fact about the homology of certain 33NUMBER:33-manifolds, which readily implies Theorem 1. In essence, we replace the divisibility condition above with the conclusion that the homology of the 22NUMBER:22-fold branched cover of the link must contain a subgroup of a certain size. Our approach has the advantage that it gives some stronger results on the embedding problem, which do not seem approachable via the combinatorial route. A slightly different argument yields a similar conclusion about other branched coverings as well. Some examples, and further remarks on embeddings, are given in the final section.

Also, if ∂⁡M𝑀OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-M\partial M is a torus T2superscript𝑇2italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT^{2}, and α⊂T𝛼𝑇italic-alpha RELOP:subset-of italic-T\alpha\subset T is a simple closed curve which does not bound a disc, then let M⁢(α)𝑀𝛼italic-M OPEN:( italic-alpha CLOSE:)M(\alpha) denote the result of Dehn filling with slope α𝛼italic-alpha\alpha. (In other words, glue S1×D2superscript𝑆1superscript𝐷2italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{1}\times D^{2} to M𝑀italic-MM so that ∂⁡D2superscript𝐷2OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\partial D^{2} is glued to α𝛼italic-alpha\alpha.)

The remark follows by reversing the roles of α,β𝛼𝛽italic-alpha PUNCT:, italic-beta\alpha,\beta and α′,β′superscript𝛼′superscript𝛽′italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\alpha^{\prime},\beta^{\prime}.
Some further results on the embedding problem, using invariant derived from the Kauffman bracket, can be found in the recent preprint [1].

div.p: Now we turn to the situation at hand, and consider the homology of N𝑁italic-NN, which we place into the long exact sequence of the pair (N,M)𝑁𝑀OPEN:( italic-N PUNCT:, italic-M CLOSE:)(N,M).

div.p: Since c⁢|T1⁢(M)|⁢ ⁢|H1⁢(N)|𝑐subscript𝑇1𝑀 subscript𝐻1𝑁italic-c VERTBAR:| italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) VERTBAR:|c\,|T_{1}(M)|\ \vrule height 12.0pt depth 6.0pt width 1px\ |H_{1}(N)| the theorem follows.

First, let us observe that Theorem 2 implies Theorem 1. The basic point is that the 22NUMBER:22-fold cover of the ball, branched along a trivial tangle, is S1×D2superscript𝑆1superscript𝐷2italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{1}\times D^{2}. The different ways of completing a tangle 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T} to a link give rise to different Dehn fillings of M𝑀italic-MM = the 22NUMBER:22-fold cover of the ball, branched along 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T}. It is easy to see that the meridians of the solid tori corresponding to the numerator n⁢(𝒯)𝑛𝒯italic-n OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:)n({{\cal T}}) and denominator d⁢(𝒯)𝑑𝒯italic-d OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:)d({{\cal T}}) have intersection number ±1plus-or-minus1ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1\pm 1 in T=∂⁡M𝑇𝑀italic-T RELOP:equals OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-MT=\partial M and thus generate H1⁢(T)subscript𝐻1𝑇italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)H_{1}(T). Now if 𝒯↪ℒ↪𝒯ℒcaligraphic-T ARROW:hookrightarrow caligraphic-L{{\cal T}}\hookrightarrow{{\cal L}} as in Theorem 1, there is an embedding M⊂N𝑀𝑁italic-M RELOP:subset-of italic-NM\subset N, where N𝑁italic-NN is the 22NUMBER:22-fold cover of the 33NUMBER:33-sphere branched along ℒℒcaligraphic-L{\cal L}. The 22NUMBER:22-fold cover of the ball, branched along a trivial tangle, is a solid torus. Hence the hypotheses of Theorem 2 are satisfied, and we get that

div.p: Second, the proof gives a somewhat stronger condition, involving the homology groups themselves, rather than their orders. We give the statement in terms of the homology of 33NUMBER:33-manifolds, with the understanding that passing to the 2-fold cover of a link gives rise to a restriction on embeddings of tangles in links.

Then there is an injection of Z/c⊕T1⁢(M)direct-sumnormal-Z𝑐subscript𝑇1𝑀bold-Z MULOP:divide italic-c ADDOP:direct-sum italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:){\bf Z}/c\oplus T_{1}(M) into H1⁢(N)subscript𝐻1𝑁italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:)H_{1}(N), where c𝑐italic-cc has the same significance as in the proof of Theorem 2.

div.p: In applying these results to specific tangles, the most useful part of the conclusion is the fact that the inclusion map of M𝑀italic-MM into N𝑁italic-NN induces an injection on T1⁢(M)subscript𝑇1𝑀italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:)T_{1}(M). This is true in a more general setting, by an argument which is perhaps more conceptual than the calculation proving Theorem 2.

div.p:
Proof of Theorem 3: The linking pairing λ:T1⁢(M)×T1⁢(M,∂⁡M)→𝐐/𝐙:𝜆→subscript𝑇1𝑀subscript𝑇1𝑀𝑀𝐐𝐙italic-lambda METARELOP:colon italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:) MULOP:times italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:, OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-M CLOSE:) ARROW:to bold-Q MULOP:divide bold-Z\lambda:T_{1}(M)\times T_{1}(M,\partial M)\to{\bf Q}/{\bf Z} is non-degenerate, by Poincaré duality. So if x∈T1⁢(M)𝑥subscript𝑇1𝑀italic-x RELOP:element-of italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:)x\in T_{1}(M) is non-zero, there is an element y∈T1⁢(M,∂⁡M)𝑦subscript𝑇1𝑀𝑀italic-y RELOP:element-of italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:, OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-M CLOSE:)y\in T_{1}(M,\partial M) with λ⁢(x,y)𝜆𝑥𝑦italic-lambda OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-y CLOSE:)\lambda(x,y) non-zero in 𝐐/𝐙𝐐𝐙bold-Q MULOP:divide bold-Z{\bf Q}/{\bf Z}; represent each of these by (absolute or relative) cycles with the same names. Since ∂⁡M𝑀OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-M\partial M is connected, H1⁢(M)→H1⁢(M,∂⁡M)→subscript𝐻1𝑀subscript𝐻1𝑀𝑀italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:) ARROW:to italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:, OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-M CLOSE:)H_{1}(M)\to H_{1}(M,\partial M) is surjective, so y𝑦italic-yy lifts to y¯∈H1⁢(M)¯𝑦subscript𝐻1𝑀OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-y ARG:end RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:)\bar{y}\in H_{1}(M). There is no good reason that y¯¯𝑦OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-y ARG:end\bar{y} represents a torsion class in M𝑀italic-MM, but by hypothesis it is a torsion class in N𝑁italic-NN. Now λ⁢(x,i*⁢y¯)𝜆𝑥subscript𝑖¯𝑦italic-lambda OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-y ARG:end CLOSE:)\lambda(x,i_{*}\bar{y}) (as calculated in N𝑁italic-NN) may be calculated as the intersection number of y¯¯𝑦OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-y ARG:end\bar{y} with a 22NUMBER:22-chain bounding n⋅x⋅𝑛𝑥italic-n MULOP:cdot italic-xn\cdot x, and C𝐶italic-CC can be chosen to lie in M𝑀italic-MM since x𝑥italic-xx is a torsion class in M𝑀italic-MM. Remark: It is not possible to deduce Theorem 2 (and hence Theorem 1) from Theorem 3. To do so would amount to proving that (in the notation of Theorem 2) gcd⁡(|M⁢(α)|,|M⁢(β)|)=|T1⁢(M)|𝑀𝛼𝑀𝛽subscript𝑇1𝑀OPFUNCTION:gcd OPEN:( VERTBAR:| italic-M OPEN:( italic-alpha CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| PUNCT:, VERTBAR:| italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| CLOSE:) RELOP:equals VERTBAR:| italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:) VERTBAR:|\gcd(|{M(\alpha)}|,|{M(\beta)}|)=|T_{1}(M)|. This same example shows that the hypothesis in Theorem 3, that H1⁢(N)subscript𝐻1𝑁italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:)H_{1}(N) be torsion, is necessary. For if N𝑁italic-NN is obtained by filling M𝑀italic-MM with slope α+β𝛼𝛽italic-alpha ADDOP:plus italic-beta\alpha+\beta, then H1⁢(N)≅𝐙subscript𝐻1𝑁𝐙italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals bold-ZH_{1}(N)\cong{\bf Z}, and so T1⁢(M)subscript𝑇1𝑀italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:)T_{1}(M) doesn’t inject.

Theorem 3 may be applied to branched covers of tangles, of degrees other than 22NUMBER:22. In applying this remark, one must take care, because for k>2𝑘2italic-k RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:2k>2 the k𝑘italic-kk-fold covers of the ball, branched along 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T} are not uniquely specified by the branch locus. These different covers may well have differing homology groups, so in practice, one might have to calculate the homology groups for all of the different possibilities.

p.span: Suppose that T↪Lnormal-↪normal-Tnormal-Lcaligraphic-T ARROW:hookrightarrow caligraphic-L{{\cal T}}\hookrightarrow{{\cal L}}, and that N𝑁italic-NN is a k-fold cover of S3superscript𝑆3italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{3} branched along Lnormal-Lcaligraphic-L{\cal L}. Let M𝑀italic-MM be the induced cover of B3superscript𝐵3italic-B POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endB^{3}, branched along Tnormal-Tcaligraphic-T{\cal T}. If N𝑁italic-NN is a rational homology sphere, then T1⁢(M)subscript𝑇1𝑀italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:)T_{1}(M) is a subgroup of T1⁢(N)subscript𝑇1𝑁italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:)T_{1}(N).

div.p: Most of the results so far have concerned only the torsion part of the homology, but there are some things which can be said about the torsion-free part of the homology. One simple result is the following.

div.p: The proof is straightforward; if the quantity dim⁡(H1⁢(M;𝐐))-gdimensionsubscript𝐻1𝑀𝐐𝑔LIMITOP:dimension OPEN:( italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:; bold-Q CLOSE:) CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-g\dim(H_{1}(M;{\bf Q}))-g is greater than zero, then there is a subspace of that dimension in H1⁢(M;𝐐)subscript𝐻1𝑀𝐐italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:; bold-Q CLOSE:)H_{1}(M;{\bf Q}) which pairs non-trivially with a subspace of H2⁢(M;𝐐)subscript𝐻2𝑀𝐐italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:; bold-Q CLOSE:)H_{2}(M;{\bf Q}) of the same dimension. Hence both of these inject into the homology of N𝑁italic-NN.

p.span: It is not hard to give examples where the homological approach gives more information than can be deduced from the determinants alone. The simplest I can think of is the following. Let Tnormal-Tcaligraphic-T{{\cal T}} be the tangle

According to [2], the numerator and denominator of this tangle may be calculated as the numerator and denominator of the fraction obtained by the grade school addition of fractions, without canceling common factors:

This would allow, in principle, that Tnormal-Tcaligraphic-T{{\cal T}} might embed in a 22NUMBER:22-bridge knot (or link) corresponding to the fraction 9⁢p/q9𝑝𝑞NUMBER:9 italic-p MULOP:divide italic-q9p/q, for the determinant of such a knot is 9⁢p9𝑝NUMBER:9 italic-p9p. But we calculate below that for M=𝑀absentitalic-M RELOP:equalsM= the 22NUMBER:22-fold cover of B3superscript𝐵3italic-B POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endB^{3} branched along Tnormal-Tcaligraphic-T{{\cal T}}, we have H1⁢(M)=Z⊕Z/3⊕Z/3subscript𝐻1𝑀direct-sumnormal-Znormal-Z3normal-Z3italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:) RELOP:equals bold-Z ADDOP:direct-sum bold-Z MULOP:divide NUMBER:3 ADDOP:direct-sum bold-Z MULOP:divide NUMBER:3H_{1}(M)={\bf Z}\oplus{\bf Z}/3\oplus{\bf Z}/3, whereas the 22NUMBER:22-fold cover of a 22NUMBER:22-bridge knot or link has cyclic homology.

div.p: The calculation of H1⁢(M)subscript𝐻1𝑀italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M CLOSE:)H_{1}(M) proceeds as in the usual calculation of 22NUMBER:22-fold covers branched along knots, as described in §6 of [3]. If surgery is done on the middle crossings in each of the three ±1/3plus-or-minus13ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3\pm 1/3 tangles which make up 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T}, then 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T} becomes trivial. Straightening it out (for the purpose of drawing the branched cover, it’s legal to move the endpoints around) gives the surgery picture in Figure 2.

section.h2: 4 An obstruction to embedding in a trivial link

div.p: An obstruction to embedding tangles in the trivial link, of a somewhat different sort, may be derived from the invariants In⁢(𝒯)superscript𝐼𝑛𝒯italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:)I^{n}({{\cal T}}) defined in [4]. To explain this, we recall that for a 22NUMBER:22-component oriented link ℒ=(Lx,Ly)ℒsubscript𝐿𝑥subscript𝐿𝑦caligraphic-L RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){{\cal L}}=(L_{x},L_{y}) of linking number λ=0𝜆0italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\lambda=0, Cochran [5] defined ‘higher linking numbers’ βxn⁢(ℒ)subscriptsuperscript𝛽𝑛𝑥ℒitalic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-L CLOSE:)\beta^{n}_{x}({{\cal L}}) and βyn⁢(ℒ)subscriptsuperscript𝛽𝑛𝑦ℒitalic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-L CLOSE:)\beta^{n}_{y}({{\cal L}}). For n=1𝑛1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1 these are both equal to the Sato-Levine invariant [6] while for n>1𝑛1italic-n RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1n>1 they depend on the ordering of the components. For a tangle 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{{\cal T}} it is possible to choose a tangle sum with a trivial tangle (a closure of 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T} in the terminology of [4]) to get a link ℒℒcaligraphic-L{{\cal L}} with λ=β1=0𝜆superscript𝛽10italic-lambda RELOP:equals italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\lambda=\beta^{1}=0. There is no canonical choice for ℒℒcaligraphic-L{\cal L}, but we showed that

p.span: Suppose that Tnormal-Tcaligraphic-T{{\cal T}} is a tangle with no loops such that T↪J=normal-↪normal-Tnormal-Jabsentcaligraphic-T ARROW:hookrightarrow caligraphic-J RELOP:equals{{\cal T}}\hookrightarrow{\cal J}= the trivial 22NUMBER:22-component link. Then In⁢(T)=0superscript𝐼𝑛normal-T0italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0I^{n}({{\cal T}})=0 for all n≥2𝑛2italic-n RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:2n\geq 2.

div.p: Proof: Consider first a 22NUMBER:22-string tangle 𝒦𝒦caligraphic-K{\cal K} with no loops, and the 4-punctured sphere ΣΣSigma\Sigma in the boundary of its exterior. Then ΣΣSigma\Sigma is compressible if and only if 𝒦𝒦caligraphic-K{\cal K} is split, where 𝒦𝒦caligraphic-K{\cal K} is split if the ball can be split into two sub-balls by a properly embedded disk with the two strings of 𝒦𝒦caligraphic-K{\cal K} lying in different sub-balls. This follows directly from the loop theorem and Dehn’s lemma. The structure of a split tangle is very simple: it is a trivial tangle possibly with knots tied in each string. The tangle is trivial if and only if there are no knots. In particular, a split tangle has In=0superscript𝐼𝑛0italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0I^{n}=0 for all n𝑛italic-nn, because it has a completion which is a split link, which in turn has all of its βn=0superscript𝛽𝑛0italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\beta^{n}=0.

Now consider a tangle 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T} with In≠0superscript𝐼𝑛0italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0I^{n}
eq 0, and suppose that 𝒯↪𝒥↪𝒯𝒥caligraphic-T ARROW:hookrightarrow caligraphic-J{{\cal T}}\hookrightarrow{\cal J}, or in other words that 𝒥𝒥caligraphic-J{\cal J} splits as a sum 𝒯+𝒯′𝒯superscript𝒯′caligraphic-T ADDOP:plus caligraphic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal T}}+{{\cal T}}^{\prime}. From the preceding paragraph In⁢(𝒯)≠0superscript𝐼𝑛𝒯0italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0I^{n}({{\cal T}})
eq 0 implies that the surface ΣΣSigma\Sigma is incompressible in the exterior of 𝒯𝒯caligraphic-T{\cal T}. But then ΣΣSigma\Sigma must be compressible in the exterior of 𝒯′superscript𝒯′caligraphic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal T}}^{\prime}. For if it weren’t then ΣΣSigma\Sigma would be an incompressible 44NUMBER:44-punctured sphere in the exterior of the unlink. Applying the preceding paragraph once more, it follows that 𝒯′superscript𝒯′caligraphic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal T}}^{\prime} is split. If there is a knot in one of the strands of 𝒯′superscript𝒯′caligraphic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal T}}^{\prime}, then that would give a knot in the corresponding component of the unlink, which cannot be. It follows from all of this that 𝒯′superscript𝒯′caligraphic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal T}}^{\prime} must in fact be a trivial tangle, so that the the unlink 𝒯+𝒯′𝒯superscript𝒯′caligraphic-T ADDOP:plus caligraphic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal T}}+{{\cal T}}^{\prime} may be used to calculate In⁢(𝒯)superscript𝐼𝑛𝒯italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:)I^{n}({{\cal T}}) and show that it is zero. This contradicts our assumption that In⁢(𝒯)≠0superscript𝐼𝑛𝒯0italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0I^{n}({{\cal T}})
eq 0.
The tangles cited in [4] give rise to examples of tangles which cannot be embedded in a trivial link.

We close with a few remarks on some of the questions raised at the end of [2]. One question concerned the existence of a family of completions of any tangle with 2⁢t2𝑡NUMBER:2 italic-t2t strands, which would play the role of the numerator and denominator of a 22NUMBER:22-string tangle. Following the proof of Theorems 2 and 3 we see how to construct such a family. Note that the 22NUMBER:22-fold branched cover of a trivial 2⁢t2𝑡NUMBER:2 italic-t2t-tangle is a handlebody of genus 2⁢t-12𝑡1NUMBER:2 italic-t ADDOP:minus NUMBER:12t-1. By twisting the strings around, one can vary the attaching of this complementary handlebody so as to kill of the homology of ∂⁡M𝑀OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-M\partial M in various fillings. The gcdOPFUNCTION:gcd\gcd of the orders of the homology of all these fillings then would have to divide the determinant of any link in which the tangle was embedded.

Another generalization of a tangle pointed out in §14 of [2] is an embedded arc (or more generally a 11NUMBER:11-manifold) in a more complicated submanifold of S3superscript𝑆3italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{3}, such as a solid torus. In particular, Krebes asks whether a particular arc 𝒜𝒜caligraphic-A{\cal A} in a S1×D2superscript𝑆1superscript𝐷2italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{1}\times D^{2} (Figure 17 of [2]) can sit inside an unknot. Our approach, especially Corollary 2 gives (in principle) an obstruction, if there were torsion in the homology of some cover of S1×D2superscript𝑆1superscript𝐷2italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{1}\times D^{2} branched along 𝒜𝒜caligraphic-A{\cal A}. Unfortunately, it seems that the homology of all of the cylic covers of the solid torus, branched along this arc, is torsion-free. Hence we cannot apply Theorem 3 to deduce anything about embeddings of this pair in a link. Likewise, it does not seem possible to use Theorem 4, because the rational homology of each of the cyclic branched covers is the same as for a trivial arc.
